questions.questionText:
In the study of calculus, \( 3x^3 - 5x + 2 \) it is essential to understand the fundamental concepts of integration and differentiation. Consider the following integral:

 \( \int_{0}^{2} (3x^3 - 5x + 2) \, dx. \)
 Calculate this integral to find the area under the curve defined by the function \( 3x^3 - 5x + 2 \) from \( x = 0 \) to \( x = 2. \) Next, examine the following differential equation: \( \frac{dy}{dx} = 2x \cdot e^x. \) Solve this differential equation to find the general solution. The solution involves integrating a product of a polynomial and an exponential function, which can be approached using integration by parts. Also, consider the function \( f(x) = \sin(x) \cdot \cos(x) \). Find the derivative of this function using the product rule. The product rule states that if \( u(x) \) and \( v(x) \) are functions of \( x \), then the derivative of \( u(x) \cdot v(x) \) is given by \( u'(x) \cdot v(x) + u(x) \cdot v'(x) \). Applying this rule will give you the derivative of \( \sin(x) \cdot \cos(x) \). Finally, analyze the behavior of the function \( g(x) = \frac{1}{x^2 + 1} \) as \( x \) approaches infinity. Determine the limit of this function as \( x \) goes to infinity.

To understand the fundamental concepts of integration and differentiation. Consider the following integral: \( \int_{0}^{2} (3x^3 - 5x + 2) \, dx. \)
 Calculate this integral to find the area under the curve defined by the function \( 3x^3 - 5x + 2 \) from \( x = 0 \) to \( x = 2. \) Next, examine the following differential equation: \( \frac{dy}{dx} = 2x \cdot e^x. \) Solve this differential equation to find the general solution. The solution involves integrating a product of a polynomial and an exponential function, which can be approached using integration by parts. Also, consider the function \( f(x) = \sin(x) \cdot \cos(x) \). Find the derivative of this function using the product rule. The product rule states that if \( u(x) \) and \( v(x) \) are functions of \( x \), then the derivative of \( u(x) \cdot v(x) \) is given by \( u'(x) \cdot v(x) + u(x) \cdot v'(x) \). Applying this rule will give you the derivative of \( \sin(x) \cdot \cos(x) \). Finally, analyze the behavior of the function \( g(x) = \frac{1}{x^2 + 1} \) as \( x \) approaches arbitrary. Determine the limit of this function as \( x \) goes to arbitrary.
